fields.description:
The dashboard "All plans" were breaked when a user use html in his svn comment. We thought it was one of theses comments :

Removed <head>,<body> and .page <div> from JSPs
or
Removed <div class="topmenu"> and changed <div class="sidemenu"> to <div class="navigation">
or
Removed <div class="topmenu"> and changed <div class="sidemenu"> to <

We fix it with a manual build (it was the reason of the build who breaks the page).
fields.summary: Breaks of display in "All plans" Dashboard when svn comments have html inside.

fields.description:
In a number of our builds we're starting to see failures due to the inability to delete lucene locks from the /tmp area.  We see errors like the following in our builds:

java.io.IOException: Cannot delete /tmp/lucene-18eec490b2669271cd1934bf01ac6c3b-write.lock
	at org.apache.lucene.store.FSDirectory.create(FSDirectory.java:210)
	at org.apache.lucene.store.FSDirectory.getDirectory(FSDirectory.java:144)
	at org.springmodules.lucene.index.support.FSDirectoryFactoryBean.afterPropertiesSet(FSDirectoryFactoryBean.java:65)
	at org.springmodules.lucene.index.support.FSDirectoryFactoryBeanTests.testGetObjectWithCreationWriter(FSDirectoryFactoryBeanTests.java:122)

If you'd like to see an example:  http://build.springframework.org:8085/browse/MOD-HEAD-49/test/org.springmodules.lucene.index.support.FSDirectoryFactoryBeanTests

We saw this occasionally in Bamboo 1.0 but now that we've gone to 1.0.1 we're seeing it a whole lot.
fields.summary: Cannot delete lucene locks from /tmp
Cannot view logs of latest build

fields.description:
On the Bamboo section of the website, there's no obvious navigation option for someone who just wants to watch the screencasts. You have to go hunting through the feature tour.

How about one (or both) of:

* A "screencast inside" graphic for those steps on the feature tour that have videos
* An "all screencasts" index page
fields.summary: Have an index of screencasts in website

fields.description:
When any perforce command executes, it should debug *all* of its output to the log.debug stream

This is so we can tell people to add a logging level for their Perforce commands to enable debug logging if they have problems (we should add a commented out version of this to the log.4j.properties)
fields.summary: Perforce commands need better logging

after downloading the new patched version 1.0.1 Specifying the Bamboo home, I get:

./bamboo.sh: syntax error at line 80: `CLASSPATH=$CLASSPATH$PATH_SEPARATOR$' unexpected

fields.description: If you try to test the JIRA integration without having the remote API turned on is handled poorly - you can only find this out by looking in the server log (see attached). The GUI just prints an error statement 'Failed to connect to remote JIRA server'. This error reporting could be handled better in the GUI.
fields.summary: Not having JIRA's Remote API enabled is handled poorly

fields.description:
When you enter a malformed email address to the build notifications screen, the build notifications fail silently.

An example is foo.bar.@domain.com.

Bamboo fails to send emails, but this failure doesn't appear anywhere (apart from the server log - see attached).

I suggest you parse the email address when the screen is edited rather than at the point of time when the notification event gets triggered.
fields.summary: Entering syntactically incorrect mail recipiants is handled poorly

fields.description:
With version 1.0 of Bamboo, a build plan is attached to only one build project.

As developper of a product that have many parts (modules) and for which we supports many versions, we use to track builds following two axes:

1) QA / Product management people like to track the builds of a complete version of the product (aka the build of all modules wich sources are on the same SCM branch)

2) Developers of a module like to track the builds of all versions of the module they're working on.

I think we could achieve this if a build plan in bamboo could be attached to two projects.

Let support we have moduleA and moduleB (moduleA + moduleB = the complete product), and versions (SCM branches) 1.0 and 2.0 of each module (moduleA version X + moduleB version X = version X of the product).

We would like to have 4 projects:
* development branch 1.0.x
* development branch 2.0.x
* module A
* module B

We'd like to have 4 build plans, each one associated to two project:
* "build of moduleA on development branch 1.0.x", associated to "development branch 1.0.x" and "moduleA"
* build of modulesB on development branch 1.0.X, associated to "development branch 1.0.x" and "moduleB"
* build of moduleA on development branch 2.0.x, associated to "development branch 2.0.x" and "moduleA"
* build of moduleB on development branch 2.0.x , associated to "development branch 2.0.x" and "moduleB"

This would be a realy usefull enhancement to Bamboo.
fields.summary: Make it possible to attach a build plan to multiple projects

fields.description:
We need to decouple a BuildRequired queue from the ChangeDetectionQueue.

This is to make sure that manual builds are responded to quickly and doesn't have to rely on the change detection queue to execute.
fields.summary: Need a BuildRequired queue

fields.description: The BuildChangeDetector should only really run as a Quartz job, rather than just looping over the various plans.
fields.summary: BuildChanageDetector should only run on a Quartz schedule

fields.description:
We have duplicate JARs in our classpath. Having two of these buggers is a recipe for unruly behaviour.

# commons-logging 1.0.4 and 1..0
# commons-beanutils-core-1.7.0.jar & commons-beanutils-1.6.jar
# opensymphony-oscore-2.2.4.jar & oscore-oscore-2.2.4.jar


We need to pretty much figure out where the dupe jars are coming from and then "exclude" it from the pom.xml
fields.summary: Duplicate JARs in classpath

fields.description: See the attached [^BAM-988.log]
fields.summary: Error when entered License Key

fields.description: Emails should have some of the smarts there are in the front end. If a build fails, it should mention and display some information about the build that caused the failure (and how).

fields.description:
When building a plugin, the following warning is spat out:

[WARNING] POM for 'atlassian-user:atlassian-user:pom:2007-02-20:compile' is invalid. It will be ignored for artifact resolution. Reason: Not a v4.0.0 POM.
fields.summary: Invalid POM for atlassian-user

8/03/2007 12:52:45 net.sf.hibernate.util.JDBCExceptionReporter logExceptions

java.lang.NullPointerException
        at org.springframework.orm.hibernate.SessionFactoryUtils.closeSessionOrRegisterDeferredClose(SessionFactoryUtils.java:709)

fields.description:
When you go from the homepage to the latest build for a plan, you go to an URL like this one:
http://localhost:13000/browse/SCPPUB-CORE/latest

This results in several freemarker template exceptions that occur when rendering the links in the navigation tabs. This error does not occur when you have a build number instead

fields.summary: Freemarker template error when viewing 'latest' builds

fields.description: This is due to the Mail jar not being compiled for JDK 1.4.
fields.summary: Bamboo fails to start under JDK 1.4

fields.description: If we do a check in while the build is running, that check-in won't trigger a new build after the current build finishes. Instead we have to wait for the next check-in to trigger a build to get a build with the first check-in.
fields.summary: Checkins during a build don't seem to trigger another build after the current one finished
Clicking on Tests tab in Build Result Summary renders empty screen

fields.description:
Bamboo's BuildChangeDetector does not take time zones in to consideration when asking Perforce for changes. All Perforce commands assume the time zone of the server. In our case the Perfrorce server runs on PST and the Bamboo server on UTC. The effect is that Bamboo never builds from changes detected in the VCS. The changes are detected and Bamboo issues a p4 changes command using the current date and the date since last build. This command return zero in our case since the server is 8 hours ahead. 

I temporarily solved the problem by passing system property user.timezone in the wrapper config.
fields.summary: Different time zone on Perforce server does not work

fields.description:
The pom.xml in the template project refers to a com.atlassian.bamboo:atlassian-bamboo-web:1.1-SNAPSHOT dependency.

Given that the plugin would presumably be built against a stable version of Bamboo (e.g. 1.0.1), it's probably not appropriate to link to a snapshot API. A quick look around the Atlassian repository indicates that there is no published version as yet.

Pom snippet:

	<!-- This is the dependency to bamboo -->
    <dependency>
      <groupId>com.atlassian.bamboo</groupId>
	  <artifactId>atlassian-bamboo-web</artifactId>
	  <version>1.1-SNAPSHOT</version>
	</dependency>
fields.summary: Bamboo Plugin Dev Kit pom.xml has a snapshot dependency.

fields.description: I downloaded the plugin dev kit around midday today (07 March), and when I expanded it, I noticed it's full of Mac OSX files - notably a __MACOSX directory at the top, and .DS_Store files in each directory.
fields.summary: Plugin Dev Kit has Mac OSX specific files in it.

fields.description:
When I visit the Post Action configuration tab and click on edit, the list of IM addresses to send notifications to will be output like the following

[user1@chat.example.org, user2@chat.example.org]

If I were to save this form this list gets saved as it appears. The next time I edit this configuration it will be output as

[[user1@chat.example.org, user2@chat.example.org]]

and so on.

This only occurs when there is more than one address in the input box.
fields.summary: IM message recipients input accumulates square brackets on form load

fields.description: When I attempt to edit the build configuration using IE7, I get a pop-up that says: Operation aborted (IE cannot open the site : http://xx.xx.xx.xx/build/admin/edit/editBuildConfiguration.action?buildKey=xx). It also does it on the other edit buttons, such as for repository, etc.
fields.summary: Edit Configuraton broken

fields.description:
While one plan was executing I tried creation of a new one. After having pressed the "Continue" button on the perforce repository details page, the ui was blocked, no interaction any longer possible with the bamboo.

In the logfiles I detected entries like

INFO | jvm 1 | 2007/03/06 13:37:17 | /usr/local/bin/p4 -u <perforce user> -p <perforce server>:<perforce port> -c <perforce clientspec name> client -o

occuring repeatedly multiple times per second (!) without any further error message.

Maybe it was not the best idea but I renamed the p4-executable (the morning after a stop-start I had loss of data so I tried to avoid this - but this is a different story). After some time (not immediately!) this perforce server penetration stopped with

INFO | jvm 1 | 2007/03/06 14:20:37 | com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: Failed to get changes: Cannot find executable at /usr/local/bin/p4

Though bamboo itself still claims itself as running.

After stop & start all seems to be fine again (seems no data lost).

Note 1: there was currently executing another plan
Note 2: after re-doing same steps again this did not re-occur. But I noticed by way of a failed build that to my fault the perforce depot referring to in the plan config was not yet included in the perforce client spec.

(may be those aspects are related to this issue)
fields.summary: Bamboo penetrated perforce server with repeated requests on plan creation

fields.description:
If I create a new user in Bamboo:

Béne Clowningpants (full name, not username)

He will show up as 

BÃ©ne Clowningpants

Editing and saving this user will result in it becoming more mangled on each save.

BÃƒÂ©ne Clowningpants

I blame the French.
fields.summary: Users with non standard characters in their names show up corrupted.

fields.description:
Imagine some libraries/projects/project branches plans sharing a single resource like a database where the tests need exclusive access to while running (e.g. due to locking). So we would need to define a pool of plans of that only one may run at one time.

I believe it not sufficient to assign those plans to one dedicated build queue as this may lead to more queues than the testing machine is capable to deal with.
fields.summary: Add blocking dependencies between plans

fields.description: Some JIRA instances can be set up to accept numbers in project keys. The Bamboo parser does not currently accept this.
fields.summary: JIRA issue parser should look for numbers in project key as well.

fields.description: I'd like to be able to trigger a plan to fire when all of the JIRA tickets that constitute a release are closed.  Does Bamboo's JIRA integration have this capability?
fields.summary: Fire Off a Plan After JIRA Tickets are Closed

fields.description: I'm seeing some build errors on the "current activity" page. I think I've cleared up the problem, but I'm not really sure, since the log messages don't contain the time that the error occurred. it would be nice to get a timestamp along with the error message, and stack trace.
fields.summary: need time of error in error log

fields.description: When accessing repositories that don't respond, Bamboo should timeout after a certain period.
fields.summary: CVS and SVN Repository validation should timeout

fields.description:
From https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-13

It seems that Bamboo currently doesn't work with IBM JDK 1.4. We need to set up the environment to enable testing for this
fields.summary: Bamboo doesn't work with IBM JDK 1.4

fields.description: It appears that some of the AJAX breaks IE 7 when you're logged in as any kind of registered user.  I see it on the Plan Summary page as both a normal user and an admin.  I've told my user to stop using IE ;) but that doesn't seem to be a permanent fix for him.
fields.summary: Plan Summary does not render in IE 7 when logged in as a user

fields.summary: "FreeMarker template error!" on "Plan Summary" page in JDK 1.4

fields.description:
Cobertura is an open source coverage tool with Maven integration.  

See http://cobertura.sourceforge.net/

Would be great to see this integrated as an alternative to Clover.
fields.summary: Cobertura plugin

fields.description: Some projects use tags (e.g. current) to promote changes. It would be useful to provide a way for Bamboo to build from this tag, as well as be notified when to build based on changes in the tag contents (when new versions of files are tagged)
fields.summary: Provide ability to point to a CVS tag instead of HEAD/Branch
Make test description when tests fail on the Dash link to the failed tests.

fields.description:
(I've only tagged this as "Major" as it's majorly annoying! - there is a manual workaround)

Our main Codehaus instance (and test instances) all suffer from unreliable connections back to the SVN servers (as they are countries apart I suspect).

Whenever there is a timeout for N periods, the build is disabled. However disabling the build is not really required - it should just wait until the server is available again (perhaps with some kind of backoff algorithm.

So if there is any network outage, all my build plans are disabled - 15 odd at the moment, more in the future. That's a lot of clicking to get everything going again, and I have to notice first.

Thanks,

Ben
fields.summary: Builds tend to disable themselves far too frequently

fields.description:
On the "My Bamboo" page (i.e. my favourites) there is a section for "Broken Builds"

The link to start the build is of the form:

http://bamboo.ci.codehaus.org/build/admin/buildBuild.action?buildKey=FOCI-DEF&returnUrl=/ajax/displayMyBuildSummaries.action

When clicking on this link I end up back at http://bamboo.ci.codehaus.org/ajax/displayMyBuildSummaries.action

This page is an unstyled page and is particularly ugly - I suspect I'm being sent back to the wrong place.
fields.summary: Broken builds have incorrect links when restarting builds
Links to source is broken

fields.description: Bamboo uses an embedded database (HSQL) we should look to support external databases for reliability
fields.summary: Ability to configure a database

fields.description:
When I create a plan I don't necessarily want to let it build. 

I wanted to set up three very long running builds which rely on a single resource that can't be run in parallel ( a vmware image). I want one scheduled for low load times and want the other two to be triggered in turn. 

I can do all of this except when I create one it starts building immediately regardless of the chosen trigger mechanism.
fields.summary: Plans build when you create them regardless of their configured trigger

fields.description:
From http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=12839&tstart=0

For a plan, you sometimes want to monitor and check out from multiple repositories.
fields.summary: Allow a plan to have multiple repositories

fields.description: Instead, a wrong URL is constructed, and a user ends up on the same file history page as filename link provides. The file revision link should be consistent with what FishEye offers - annotated contents of the file as of the selected revision.
fields.summary: Changes View -> Clicking on the revision number of the file should lead to an annotated file view as of this revision

fields.description: Currently it's only possible to jump to individual file's history, but there's no way to jump to FishEye's changeset view. Add one for each revision in the build.
fields.summary: Changes tab should feature a Changeset link

fields.description:
We've specified an addition Maven 2-type builder pointing to the Maven 2.0.5 installation on our server. Maven 2.0.4 failed to resolve dependencies properly in a complex build resulting in the dependency being excluded at all. This produced compilation errors (e.g. in JMS transport module in our case).

Upgrading to Maven 2.0.5 fixed the problem and it works fine from the command line and for our current build on the Luntbuild server. However, Bamboo still seems to be using an older maven version failing to compile the module. I have confirmed the plan is using maven 2.0.5.

The error can be reproduced at http://svn.codehaus.org/mule/trunk/mule/ as of r5398 , the JMS transport will be the first to fail the compilation when run from the root of the project.
fields.summary: Bamboo uses older m2 version even when maven 2.0.5 builder configured for the plan

fields.description: The Bamboo Plugin Tutorial 1 references a "Setting up a Bamboo Project" page (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Setting+up+a+Bamboo+Plugin+Project). This page exists, but is no publicly accessible -  the page is restricted to Atlassian staff only.
fields.summary: "Setting up a Bamboo Project" doco page is  not accessible

fields.description: Bamboo's build process fails while Bamboo is processing Clover results (from a 2.0a4 beta version of Clover). Stacktrace attached. The clover XML results file is reasonably large (14 MB), which may be a factor.
fields.summary: Out of memory error while processing Clover 2.0a4 results

fields.description: Layout of the dashboard is messed up in Safari. See screenshot.
fields.summary: Long plan names do not wrap when collapsed

fields.description:
Currently when a dependant build is triggered, it will simply check out the latest source.  There should be an option to check out the same source as the parent build.

More generically, we need a way to pass context from a parent to a dependant build.
fields.summary: Dependant builds of the same source tree should build the same source as the parent

fields.description:
See attached screenshot.

On days that a build does not occur, the clover charts show 0% coverage.  This creates the false perception that somehow the test coverage actually went to 0% on those days, which is of course not the case.

Expected behavior: on days where builds do not happen, the test coverage stays constant in the chart.

Steps to replicate:

1) Set up a new project and build plan for a codebase that is integrated with Clover.  Make sure that the project has greater than 0% coverage.  For example sake, we'll say that initial coverage is at 50%.
2) On day one, build the project.  Notice the clover chart shows 50% coverage
3) On day two, do not build the project.  Notice the clover chart drops to 0% coverage (lines of code chart goes to 0 too)
4) On day three, without making any modifications to the code, manually build the project.  Notice that the coverage and lines of code charts jump right back to their previous values.
fields.summary: Clover charts are inaccurate on days that builds did not occur

fields.description: The one missing feed that I'd really like to see is one for favorite plans.  It ends up being a nice filter so you don't have to subscribe to each feed individually.
fields.summary: RSS Feed for Favorite Plans

fields.description: Hibernate sessions needs to be closed in the finally block to ensure that it gets run even in event of an exception
fields.summary: Sessions need to closed in the finally block
Upgrade jfreechart version due to concurrency bug

fields.description: Using Java Service Wrappers should be an optional path, rather than the only path since it is platform dependent (e.g. 64 bit linux, Solaris)
fields.summary: Need alternative to Java Service Wrappers for Linux
Need to convert build level plugins to use web fragments
Editing LDAP users in Bamboo

fields.description: This pretty means that import will *look* as if it worked but wil not...
fields.summary: Importing data doesn't guarantee unique ids
Smack Client does not recognize project/plan keys with numbers

fields.description:
At the moment, when setting up the SVN repo, the user is forced to enter a username and password if authentication is required.

The actual behaviour should be that the defaults to using the default cached authentication for the currently logged in user
fields.summary: SVN Repository doesn't use default authentication

fields.description:
An option to delay building after checkout detected for SVN

Under some usages, people don't want check-ins to automatically trigger a build, rather, they want Bamboo to wait a certain time period to ensure no further commits occur before triggering off the build. 

From http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257243505#257243505

{quote}
A large project with several thousand classes had some files moved between the modules. Committing from root will take too much time just to analyze the changes, so a developer decides to commit in 2 changesets, for each sub-project changed.

Now, the time window between the commits can be several minutes, but Bamboo may kick in and report a broken build, while it's only a timing problem.

Believe me, it's applicable to any version control system, and given that others supported it from the beginning, it will leave your users scratching their heads.
{quote}

This will be an optional "Advanced" option.

Some potential usage issues to be aware of:
# Bamboo won't be as responsive to commits and failures. If you have a 3 minute wait period, then there's at least a 3 minute window where the code may be in an unknown, inconsistent state
# Could lead to a build not building for a while if there are many commits to a project (ie new commits within the 3 minute window)
fields.summary: An option to delay building after checkout detected for SVN

fields.description: On days in which a new build is not made (usually holidays and weekends), Bamboo shows these days as points with no data. At a managerial and visual standpoint, seeing 0 tests, or 0 coverage can take on the wrong meaning. Perhaps some sort of ignoring days where there is no data can help.
fields.summary: Days in which build is not ran should not reflect 0 as value

fields.description: I'd like to see a build report of all projects in a plan. this is a useful report to accompany delivered software delivered a client. report would be similar to a junit report, but spanning all projects in a plan

fields.summary: NPE in LatestTwentyFiveBuildResultsFilter

fields.description:
We are checking our Bamboo configuration into perforce as a precautionary measure.  What we currently do is export the full config, then delete everything but the administration.xml and administrationConfiguration.xml.  We check these two files into Perforce.

The administrationConfiguration.xml still has a lot of things in it that it looks like are not needed for the minimal configuration to restore a system.

It would be nice if there was an option to create a 'system restore' backup - not a full export. I think you get this when you do an import - it makes a backup, so if that could just be made an option on export, that work fine.
fields.summary: Option to export minimal configuration (like backup)

fields.description: When on the "Available Builders" screen one can press edit to change the builder.  Once you do this the other builders are hidden and only one to modify is present.  The remaing row loses its existing values and the user is left to start again from scratch.  This is confusing as it seems as if you are adding a new builder rather than editing an existing one.  It also means a minor alteration to a path must be copied and pasted in again.
fields.summary: Builders edit screen not populating existing values.

fields.description:
If you setup your queues to only accept certain plans, meaning that new plans may *never* have a chance to build, this will cause the process to continuously check out and build 

The problems lies in the {{InitialBootstapBuildStrategy}} which *always* require a clean build, maybe we can just get rid of this.


From http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257243233&tstart=0#257243233
fields.summary: If an initial build has no queues to go into, it may cause repeated clean builds

fields.description: Overall coverage is a great place to start with. However, in order to track that tests are indeed being worked on, along with more code, there should be a way to see how each individual class has faired per test. Clover coverage for each class, along with (my opinion) top 10 movers in coverage would help managers and SQEs determine what should get extra attention on testing.
fields.summary: Request - Individual Class with Clover Coverage Results

fields.description:
On the Specify Source Repository screen, I have entered the subversion repository url(http://scm.fftw.com), userid and password, when it tries to connect, an error of:  'This is not a valid Subversion Repository: svn: PROPFIND of '/svn/active': 500 Internal Server Error (http://scm.fftw.com)'
Our subversion server uses the Windows Domain Authentication(mod_auth_sspi, http://www.subversionary.org/sspidomainauth), our subversion server authentication works fine with other tools such as subclipse, tortoise svn, and we are able to browse our repository via a browser.  It just doesn't work with Bamboo for some reason.

fields.description:
When Bamboo runs for some time (lets say 10 builds) it hangs repdroducbily directly after a build. The sympton is, that no one can connect to 
the webapp anymore, blocking for ever. After 8 minutes or so, the following appears in atlassian-bamboo.log:

2007-02-23 14:47:10,603 INFO [BAM:Default Queue:BuildExe] [SaveBuildTask] Indexing build results...
2007-02-23 14:55:45,547 INFO [SocketListener0-254] [SocketListener] LOW ON THREADS ((256-255+0)<2) on SocketListener0@0.0.0.0:8085
2007-02-23 14:56:00,566 WARN [Acceptor ServerSocket[addr=0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0,port=0,localport=8085]] [ThreadPool] No thread for Socket[addr=/127.0.0.1,port=56277,localport=8085]
2007-02-23 14:56:10,569 WARN [Acceptor ServerSocket[addr=0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0,port=0,localport=8085]] [ThreadPool] No thread for Socket[addr=/127.0.0.1,port=56278,localport=8085]
2007-02-23 14:56:20,573 WARN [Acceptor ServerSocket[addr=0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0,port=0,localport=8085]] [ThreadPool] No thread for Socket[addr=/127.0.0.1,port=56279,localport=8085]
....

and so on. 

A restart is the only workaround for the moment
fields.summary: LOW ON THREADS

fields.description: For some operating systems, the wrapper start up fails. For these cases, there should be a manual bamboo startup script.
fields.summary: Standalone Bamboo cannot start in certain Linux environments

fields.description:
For folks with lots of projects - it'd be great to be able to create a Plan Template to be reused across each project; the only thing which changes is the SCM locations.

e.g. for all the projects I work on, there maybe be 1-3 SCM locations (trunk & a few branches), then for each of them I want to have exactly the same plans - one for the CI and one for a nightly deploy in maven. So it'd be great if I could setup a 'Plan Template' to say this, then when creating a new project I can just refer to the plan template (which has each plan configuration inside it).

It'd just save a fair bit of UI work on the end user - rather than having to create at least 2 plans manually for each SCM root, I could just basically add 1 project and list all the multiple SCM roots and pick a plan and I've just setup (say) 6 actual plans from one or two entry screens
fields.summary: plan templates to reuse across projects

fields.description: Bamboo currently allows only for manual backups which is ok for the occasional visit to the admin jsp and doing upgrades but not for a production system. Build a task that can be scheduled to backup to a particular path in regular intervals and runs without manual intervention. (like in JIRA).
fields.summary: Automate backups with a task scheduler

fields.description:
While we've been enjoying the features of Bamboo, there's a few issues that are hard to resolve.  One of there is the methodology with the file layout structure of builds.  

For a plan, say 'TRUNK' on projects MyProject1, MyProject2, Bamboo makes a directory in /xml-data/build-dir called 'MYPROJECT1-TRUNK' and  'MYPROJECT2-TRUNK'.

If I make another plan, say 'BRANCH' on projects MyProject1, MyProject2, Bamboo makes a directory in /xml-data/build-dir called 'MYPROJECT1-BRANCH and  'MYPROJECT2-BRANCH'.

The trouble with this (for us) lies in two areas:

1.) Dependency builds between different ant project projects expect the project name to be what the SVN module is called, i.e. MyProject1.   This allows for build artifacts from MyProject1 to be fetched by MyProject2 by navigating the directory structure appropriately, i.e. Project2 gets artifacts in ../MyProject1/dist

We currently work around this issue by manually creating symbolic links in that /xml-data/build-dir directory, i.e. 'ln -s MYPROJECT1-TRUNK MyProject'

2.) Having build plans based on source control branches in the same directory causes collisions for trying to get appropriate build artifacts.  In the example above, I explained how we can work around the renaming of the projects by using symbolic links so that ant can navigate the directory path to fetch its dependencies.  However, this model fails if we are trying to have two projects with the same SVN name but from the trunk and a branch in the same directory -- the symbolic link would always have to map only to a single project.

While we haven't done it yet, I suppose the workaround would be to run a second instance of Bamboo on the same JBoss server and give it a different bamboo_home directory.


What might be nice (from our perspective, of course) is the option or ability to say to use the 'native project names' for the builds which could then maybe map out a driectory structure like:

xml-data/build-dir
   |-- TRUNK
       |--- MyProject1
       |--- MyProject2
  |--BRANCH
       |--- MyProject1
       |--- MyProject2

whereas MyProject1 and MyProject2 are the 'native svn project names' and TRUNK and BRANCH are Bamboo plans.
fields.summary: Allow new build directories per plan to be created in /xml-data/build-dir

fields.description: I'm working on setting up CI builds for the Spring project.  One of our major headaches currently is ensuring backwards compatibility with older VMs.  Basically our CI build builds with Java 5, but then needs to run the test suite against, 1.3, 1.4, 5, and 6.  As it stands now, we can only build and tests against 5 in an automated fashion and then right before release, we do some manual runs.  We'd like to automate this, but it means that we need to build with one plan and run against those same binaries with another plan using another VM.  It'd be nice to be able to either use the same build output between plans or potentially have different targets run with different VMs (which I'd guess would be a usability nightmare!).
fields.summary: Allow multiple builds to be run against same folder

fields.description: As part of our builds, we typically pass in a -propertyfile argument to the ant and point it at a property file.  While I can prepend this to the target line, it isn't exactly  the right location for values like that (I'd say putting -Ds there isn't either).  There should be an input field for property file location which would be appended in a similar way to location of the build file.
fields.summary: Add a property file entry field on the ANT Builder Configuration page
